awd_titl_txt: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Multiscale Alloy Design of HCP Alloys via Twin Mesh Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Hexagonal close packed (HCP) metals such as magnesium and titanium have the potential to provide unprecedented combinations of mechanical properties. Successful incorporation of HCP metals into engineering designs is, however, hindered by their limited plasticity.  Recent research results have introduced the exciting potential of an approach termed "twin mesh engineering". which can be applied to induce simultaneous strengthening and toughening in HCP metals. This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) award supports fundamental research to formulate the scientific framework required to design twin meshes. The integrated experimental and modeling research activities will seek to discover if alloying can be used to create the right twin mesh for high strength, high toughness HCP alloys. The resulting materials will have applications in energy efficient manufacturing where materials with attributes such as high strength, low density, room-temperature formability and cost competitiveness are required. A diverse group of student researchers will participate in the research program at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.

This award will support a research collaboration between the Universities of California at Santa Barbara, Irvine and Davis to explore interrelationships between slip and twinning in HCP metals, such as magnesium and titanium. As fine slip tends to accentuate twinning in FCC metals, one of the goals of this research will be to evaluate the influence of alloying elements on slip patterns, both experimentally and computationally using first principles. After discerning compositions that twin readily, textures that enable the formation of 3-D twin meshes in polycrystalline samples will be assessed computationally. Since slip and twinning occur concomitantly, twin meshes will block both slip and twins, leading to strengthening and toughness. The knowledge generated from this research will be used to create a multiscale tool kit, called the twin-mesh module (TMM), which when fully operational will coordinate calculations pertaining slip-twin and twin-twin interactions, processing, twin-mesh microstructure evolution, and properties. Experimentally validated TMM will accelerate materials discovery and design of HCP alloys by providing guidance on processing pathways to create 3-D twin meshes that are consistent with industrial practices. This advancement along the Materials Development Continuum will lead to expanded use of low-density, high strength, high toughness alloys, reducing weight and fuel consumption.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this DMREF collaborative research program was to respond to the challenge of accelerating materials discovery and implementation by constructing a fundamental knowledge base to design materials from basic principles that have specific combinations of strength and toughness. Specifically, an original multiscale twin-mesh module was applied to guide selection of alloying elements for twin-mesh engineered hexagonal close packed alloys, based on the hypothesis in our previous NSF DMREF program that twin meshes, defined hereafter as two or more intersecting arrays of twins within a grain, can be engineered to attain unprecedented combinations of strength and toughness in hexagonal close packed metals. To achieve the above goal, research tasks were conducted at the University of California, Irvine, including, twin nucleation and embryo growth in Mg, atomistic modeling of alloying effects, processing and characterization of materials with twin mesh microstructures to identify deformation mechanisms, analysis of mechanical behavior for select geometries and compositions, and the application of machine learning to describe appropriate microstructural features that lead to twin formation. 

Molecular dynamics simulations were conducted to reveal the initial growth mechanisms of a twin embryo in a single crystal Mg, and an analytical model was developed to describe the evolution of twin length and thickness with time. The results provide a clear and consistent description of the early stages of twin embryo growth, which fills an important gap in the understanding of twinning. High-throughput atomistic simulations were performed to reveal the unique effect of solute atoms on twin variants selection in Mg alloys. This work reveals a previously unknown effect of alloying on twinning and thereby benefits continuously emerging strategies for improving Mg properties via alloy design. Experimental investigation into the formation of twin meshes and their effect on toughening Mg was explored, with an effective surface milling approach for fabrication of Mg microstructure showing gradients in both grain size and density of twin meshes. The results show that the fraction of finer grains, density of deformation twins, and intersecting twin-twin junctions increase with an increase in impact energy. The correlation in microstructure variation with site-specific mechanical response indicates that twin meshes can activate more slip systems, increase strain hardening, and randomize texture, which result in higher uniform plastic strain. In-situ transmission electron microscopy experiments provide visualization and validation of twin nucleation and early-stage growth, in combination with finite element analysis of stress states during deformation under an applied axial compression to single-crystal Mg pillars with different geometries. The results show that the early-stage formation of a twin nucleus associated with instability of plastic flow can be controlled by tailoring the sample geometry. Furthermore, with our strategically designed truncated wedge-shaped pillars, the boundary of a twin embryo is observed to consist of basal-prismatic and prismatic-basal interfaces. The results reveal that twin nucleation occurs through a pure-shuffle mechanism, and a crystal geometry dependent twin growth mechanism of the twin nucleus at the early-stage growth associated with instability of plasticity flow, which can be dominated either by slower movement of prismatic-basal boundary steps, or by faster glide-shuffle along the twinning plane.

This DMREF/collaborative research program has promoted fundamental understanding of twinning to further understand deformation from a scientific standpoint and the microstructure design principles to engineer metals with enhanced behavior from a technological standpoint. The results/findings generated through the project have an impact on meeting the challenge of accelerating materials discovery and implementation by constructing a fundamental knowledge base to design materials from basic principles that have specific combinations of strength and toughness, via formulation of the scientific framework required to design twin meshes that can be used to attain unprecedented combinations of strength and toughness in hexagonal close packed metals. The program has enriched the training program of graduate students, undergraduate students, and post-doctoral researchers, as well as outreach activities at UC Irvine.  The research activities have strengthened intellectual collaborations and academic exchanges between UC Irvine, UC Davis, and UC Santa Barbara via collaborative research efforts by combining experimental investigation and computational modeling.  

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2023
Modified by: Julie M Schoenung
